newsitem.title: USA: FCC pulls some MobileMedia paging licenses.
newsitem.headline: FCC pulls some MobileMedia paging licenses.

text.p: The U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has terminated nearly 300 paging licenses held by MobileMedia Corp, MobileMedia said on Wednesday.

Specifically, the FCC terminated approximately 185 authorizations for unconstructed paging facilities and 99 authorizations for facilities completed after the expiration date of their construction permits.
MobileMedia is permitted to operate from those completed facilities on an interim basis until the FCC takes further action, the company said.
The FCC's action does not affect other existing paging facilities or MobileMedia's nationwide paging authorizations, the company said.

Further, the FCC dismissed approximately 94 applications for fill-in sites around existing paging stations as defective because they were predicated on unconstructed facilties. Those applications had been filed under the "40-mile rule," MobileMedia said.
The FCC issued a Public Notice relating to the status of the authorizations on Monday.
MobileMedia in December said it might seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after it failed to make a scheduled $5.6 million interest payment on its 9-3/8 percent senior subordinated debt due 2007.

The company said it was uncertain how the FCC notice would affect current and future operations, but it "could have a material adverse impact upon the financial condition or operations of the company." The company had said it discovered misrepresentations and other violations which occurred during the licensing procedure for six percent to seven percent of its approximate 8,000 local transmission one-way paging stations.
